In children, AML is very rare, accounting for 1-2% of all childhood cancers. However, the prognosis for AML in children is generally better than in adults due to the lower risk of chemotherapy-induced toxicity and the use of more aggressive treatment regimens.

Rationale: FLT3 mutations are a common genetic alteration in Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) and are associated with poorer prognosis. In a 13-year-old male patient with AML and a FLT3 mutation, I would first confirm the diagnosis through a bone marrow biopsy or blood tests. Once the diagnosis is confirmed, I would consider enrollment in a clinical trial investigating targeted therapies such as midostaurin or gilteritinib, which are FLT3 inhibitors specifically approved for use in AML patients with this mutation. These therapies have been shown to improve over all survival and reduce the risk of relapse in patients with FLT3-mutated AML. In addition, I would also consider traditional chemotherapy and/or stem cell transplant
